text:
Shouldn't this work in Julia 1.6:

```mylist = ["a", "b", "c"]
findfirst(["a"], mylist)```
Instead, I get an error like this:

```ERROR: MethodError: no method matching findfirst(::Vector{String}, ::Vector{String})
Closest candidates are:
  findfirst(::Function, ::Union{AbstractString, AbstractArray}) at array.jl:1906
  findfirst(::Function, ::Any) at array.jl:1898
  findfirst(::AbstractArray) at array.jl:1824
  ...
Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope
   @ REPL[22]:1```

elements.text: Instead, I get an error like this:

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>
This works: `findall(x -> x == "a", mylist)` But I was under the impression the other syntax works in Julia 1.6. :upside_down_face:

elements.text: But I was under the impression the other syntax works in Julia 1.6.

text: You might be thinking of `findfirst(==("a"), mylist)`, not exactly sure when it started working.

elements.text: , not exactly sure when it started working.

text:
it only works for UInt8 and 16:
```julia> findfirst([UInt8(3)], UInt8.([7,3,9]))
2:2```
(I PRed this so I kind of remember, and everyone agrees this should be generalized as soon as possible

elements.text: it only works for UInt8 and 16:
(I PRed this so I kind of remember, and everyone agrees this should be generalized as soon as possible

text: (a problem of a complete generalization is that we will have to choose between `find(::Elem, ::Array)` or `find(::SubArray, ::Array)`

elements.text: (a problem of a complete generalization is that we will have to choose between

text: most likely we will not allow `find(::Elem, ::Array)` since that is rare and writing `==(x)` is not too bad

text: What’s the logic of this, I never saw it… related to `findfirst('a', "cab")`?

elements.text: What’s the logic of this, I never saw it… related to

text: we don't think of String as Vector of Chars

elements.text: we don't think of String as Vector of Chars

text: because you can't have String of String the way you have vector of vector, you don't run into ambiguity for strings

elements.text: because you can't have String of String the way you have vector of vector, you don't run into ambiguity for strings

text: But what is the logic? Why is a vector appearing like a callable? Why is it returning a range of indices, not one?

elements.text: But what is the logic? Why is a vector appearing like a callable? Why is it returning a range of indices, not one?

text: Oh, help says `findfirst([0x52, 0x62], [0x40, 0x52, 0x62, 0x63]) == 2:3` which explains a bit. But why UInt8, what’s it for?

elements.text: which explains a bit. But why UInt8, what’s it for?

text: UInt limitation is simply due to the fact that we're reusing the underlying algorithms for string search and just relaxing the methods to include UInt8,16.

elements.text: UInt limitation is simply due to the fact that we're reusing the underlying algorithms for string search and just relaxing the methods to include UInt8,16.
